content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This is absolutely terrible. I feel genuinely bad for giving somebody money for this. I’ve seen bad PC ports in my day, but this takes the cake so abruptly that I could only play the game for 3 minutes before quitting.Reasons for terrible: fixed low resolution (800x600, are you freaking kidding?!), fixed aspect ratio (THIS GAME WAS MADE FOR 16:9 PHONES, WHY IS THERE 4:3 BLACK BARS?!), horrible framerate (this is a game designed for phones 3 generations old and my GTX 970 cant render it higher than 20 fps), I thought the “3D Acceleration” was put in as an April Fool’s joke (nope), DRM in addition to Steam (don’t bother looking on the store page, they don’t mention this 3rd party DRM like normal publishers do…they have checksums built into the game that prevent ANY kind of modification of key files, so good luck trying to mod it to run normally), inaccurate click-boxes (good luck trying to click the little suns you have to continuously collect mobile-like).Buy this on your phone, or better yet download it and run it on an Android emulator like Andy. This is a great game, I’ve played it many times on my mobile. But this…this is a pathetic excuse of a port. So bad, I’m hesitant to even call it a port for fear of putting it in the same group as Sonic Adventures DX…FREAKING SONIC ADVENTURES DX IS A BETTER PC PORT! *puke*EDIT: Since so many people are downvoting this review, Im assuming theyre doing so because I said its a bad PC port. I should point out that I was incorrect; this is not a PC port, since the game was originally designed for the PC. Regardless, its still a terrible version of the game; ALL of my points (including that terrible PC ports like Sonic Adventures DX put this to shame) still stand. OK? So now you have no justification for downvoting, right? No "good" justification anyway...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												Plants vs. Zombies Game Of The Year Edition (PvZ) is a tower defense game that appeals to casual players as well as hardcore RTS enthusiasts.  You protect your home backyard and roof from a zombie infestation with a garden you plant on the fly on a 2D, 5 row landscape.  You are given a plethora of tools to help you fight back the slow moving invaders, but you can only select a limited number of weapons you can take in to each battle.  The tools you have at your disposal include resource generators, shooters/lobbers, bombs, and walls, each having advantages and disadvantages.  The zombies aren't just limited to the slow moving walkers, but rather get wildly creative, and force you to adapt to all of the different tools you have available.  No single tool is over powered.  That is where the game has the greatest strength, earning the GOTY award.  The overall balance is so well done, that the replay value is incredibly high.  Beating the game on normal (which is pretty easy) unlocks the hard mode.  Hard mode is still not too hard, but the hardest mode is within the game is Endless Survival, where the waves don't stop coming.  Casual gamers will appreciate the challenge of hard mode, but the real die hard RTS will find the real gem of Endless Survival, where you can prove your skills through endurance.  The highest my friend has ever achieved is 107 waves, which is a bit harder than it sounds.In short, if you were ever curious about how tower defense games work, you should check it out.  If you are an avid die hard rts fan, you owe it to yourself to check this one out.  What I'm saying is, check it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												A game you can pick up and play in minutes, useful for the odd few moments when you're unsure of what to play or have 5 mins and don't want to get stuck into something bigger. Plants Vs Zombies is a gun twist on a tower defense game and features you literally growing plants on your lawn, swimming pool and rooftop to stop the zombies from eating your brains.The game is quite replayable, the first run through has several stages and keeps the gameplay interesting by adding hazards such as fog, mini-games like bowling & slots and even some puzzle modes to keep all audiences interested. 2x play throughs of the adventure mode are required to see everything and you can replay the mini games & puzzles at will once they're unlocked.For the score setters, the game features survival modes & even an endless mode just to see how many waves you can last.There's also a "Zen Garden" where you grow plants without figting zombies and can have several gardens and a tree of wisdom, providing tips and codes to modify the games visuals.The game looks a little dated due to the developers sticking with a 4:3 resolution and maximised on a 1920 x 1080 screen this can look a little pixelated - that doesn't impact the gameplay and even adds some charm to the game itself.If you're looking for a casual game that will keep you interested over a long period of time and isn't overly difficult in the process, pick this up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												One of the best games in recent years. It has a funny style and even funnier game-play. You can play it casually 30 minutes once in a while or hours upon hours. The shere mass of minigames, puzzels and achievements makes this an enduring game with a lot, I mean seriously a lot, of playtime in it, easily more than a hundred hours if you want to. Or, as I said, you can just play it a short time once in a while to relax and it will still be great. You should really explore this game, including the "help" menu :), it's very original and funny. Also amazingly, this is easy to go to and still have very hard levels especially in the minigames, making it popular both among kinder-garden children and people like me at the university. Truly an unique game that will undoubtedly go into video game history and become one of the great classics!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Absolutely love this game!  The humour is excellent; witty and engaging.  Appeals to all ages from my youngest to me.  I would recommend this to anyone who fancies a challenge that doesn't demand all your time.The crux is simple: defend your home from the invading hordes of zombies who appear in some bizarre outfits to eat your brains.  Using what can only be considered a variety of genetically modified horticultural weapons, you grow your last lines of defence and battle wave after wave of zombies.This is an immensely satisfying game that will brighten any gloomy afternoon with its challenge and humour.Buy it.  Buy it now!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 20, 2012
												Plants v. Zombies is the definition of a modern casual game.  It is super accessible, has simple but clean graphics, and offers a variety of play modes.  It is a tower defense game for those who have never heard of toweer defense games.  The story mode progresses steadily until the end, adding tougher zombies as you ascend levels, but also rewarding you with different defensive plants.  In secondary plays, the story mode adds more challenges as your crazy neighbor starts to pick some of your plants for you.  For those who find story or puzzle mode too hard, you can always stare at your garden, water all your plants and poke your snail.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Probably the better version. While it's PC only, and the PvZ brand lends itself well to mobile platforms, PvZ GOTY is the game it was meant to be. Gameplay progresses nicely, and the first play through is very much new zombie = new plant. It's linear in that regard. On the second playthough Crazy Dave has a surprise that makes a replay unique. The side games and puzzles are a nice change too. Each of the games offers a new challenge. They're relatively easy to complete, but as a casual game, they offer a nice change to the base campaign. Added to this are the Zen Garden and Tree of Life. These provide longevity to the game, as filling your garden and growing the Tree require a lot of investment. Money comes quick, with half my Zen Garden filled I make about $10k in an hour. The garden, thankfully, gives the player the most bang for your time - over time the diminishing return increases. The Garden is a nice feature because you can advance the game, and go take a shower or something while your Snail collects the coins. PvZ GOTY offers something for almost everyone. I like it because I can fit a level into a short time, making it a quick, fun, distraction. I would recommend this game over buying PvZ2 on mobile - since EA took over, PvZ2 is heavily monitized and pushes micro transactions, including buy-to-win shortcuts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I LOVE this game!  We have it on multiple platforms (PC, DS, Ipad, and Iphone). It is a tower defense game that never loses its replay value. I love the cartoon aspect of it and it's fun for the whole family. You slowly build on the plant choices you get, and each plant has its own unique power. The sunflower produces sun, which is required to get your plants. The peashooter is a plant that shoots one pea at a time, thus elminating the zombies slowly. It gets more strategic as you go along and the possiblities are endless on which plants you can pick (no pun intended) to try to defeat the zombie hoard. The zombies, of course, have their own capabilities and each one you encounter makes you ponder in what way you want to eliminate them. It's all a great bit of fun, and I highly recommend this game!!

Posted: August 20, 2012
												Plants v. Zombies is the definition of a modern casual game.  It is super accessible, has simple but clean graphics, and offers a variety of play modes.  It is a tower defense game for those who have never heard of toweer defense games.  The story mode progresses steadily until the end, adding tougher zombies as you ascend levels, but also rewarding you with different defensive plants.  In secondary plays, the story mode adds more challenges as your crazy neighbor starts to pick some of your plants for you.  For those who find story or puzzle mode too hard, you can always stare at your garden, water all your plants and poke your snail.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												A game you can pick up and play in minutes, useful for the odd few moments when you're unsure of what to play or have 5 mins and don't want to get stuck into something bigger. Plants Vs Zombies is a gun twist on a tower defense game and features you literally growing plants on your lawn, swimming pool and rooftop to stop the zombies from eating your brains.The game is quite replayable, the first run through has several stages and keeps the gameplay interesting by adding hazards such as fog, mini-games like bowling & slots and even some puzzle modes to keep all audiences interested. 2x play throughs of the adventure mode are required to see everything and you can replay the mini games & puzzles at will once they're unlocked.For the score setters, the game features survival modes & even an endless mode just to see how many waves you can last.There's also a "Zen Garden" where you grow plants without figting zombies and can have several gardens and a tree of wisdom, providing tips and codes to modify the games visuals.The game looks a little dated due to the developers sticking with a 4:3 resolution and maximised on a 1920 x 1080 screen this can look a little pixelated - that doesn't impact the gameplay and even adds some charm to the game itself.If you're looking for a casual game that will keep you interested over a long period of time and isn't overly difficult in the process, pick this up.

												Plans Vs Zombies is a brilliant twist on the Tower Defence genre. The main campaign is just the right length to get the most out of the good variety of plants with which to defend your lawn from undead attackers, and the unlockable mini-games and challenge modes will easily double that playtime with different takes on the theme. The tactical decision making and resource management are deep enough to satisy a veteran gamer, while the cartoony theme and simple concept make PvZ an excellent choice for novice gamers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												Plants vs. Zombies Game Of The Year Edition (PvZ) is a tower defense game that appeals to casual players as well as hardcore RTS enthusiasts.  You protect your home backyard and roof from a zombie infestation with a garden you plant on the fly on a 2D, 5 row landscape.  You are given a plethora of tools to help you fight back the slow moving invaders, but you can only select a limited number of weapons you can take in to each battle.  The tools you have at your disposal include resource generators, shooters/lobbers, bombs, and walls, each having advantages and disadvantages.  The zombies aren't just limited to the slow moving walkers, but rather get wildly creative, and force you to adapt to all of the different tools you have available.  No single tool is over powered.  That is where the game has the greatest strength, earning the GOTY award.  The overall balance is so well done, that the replay value is incredibly high.  Beating the game on normal (which is pretty easy) unlocks the hard mode.  Hard mode is still not too hard, but the hardest mode is within the game is Endless Survival, where the waves don't stop coming.  Casual gamers will appreciate the challenge of hard mode, but the real die hard RTS will find the real gem of Endless Survival, where you can prove your skills through endurance.  The highest my friend has ever achieved is 107 waves, which is a bit harder than it sounds.In short, if you were ever curious about how tower defense games work, you should check it out.  If you are an avid die hard rts fan, you owe it to yourself to check this one out.  What I'm saying is, check it out.
